text: hello I'm Darren Davis and I'm the
manager of the Souza isv engineering
team this demonstration will show a new
feature added to soua Studio the ability
to build and manage Amazon ec2
appliances I have already built an
Apache web server in Souza Studio that I
want to deploy to Amazon ec2 by
selecting this Appliance and looking
under the build tab you can see that
Souza Studio supports building Amazon
ec2 images here you can see I have
already built the default dis image as
well as an Amazon ec2 image that is
ready to be uploaded to Amazon web
services I select the upload to ec2 link
to begin the upload process before you
can upload to Amazon web services you
need to enter your Amazon credentials
into soua Studio here you can see that I
already entered my access key and secret
access key for my account on Amazon web
services you can get your CR credentials
from your account by selecting the link
in soua studio which will direct you to
the correct page on Amazon's
website here you can see your access key
and select show to see your secret
access key you just cut and paste those
keys into the form on the Souza Studio
page select your default region and then
save your changes now you are ready to
upload Amazon ec2 appliances so I now
select the Apache web server Appliance I
can select a version and the region then
I start the upload of the appliance
which gets added to the upload
queue my upload of the Apache web server
Appliance has completed before I launch
this instance of my Apache web server
I'm going to go to the Amazon web
services Management console and refresh
my
resources you can see that it gets
updated with information on my uploaded
Appliance if I look into my Ami images
and refresh the console you can see the
Apache web server server instance that
was uploaded by susza studio is now
available before I launch the instance I
need to make sure the security group is
updated with the correct services for
this
Appliance if I refresh the security
groups you can see sua Studio created a
group for my Apache web server Appliance
I can go back to soua studio and launch
an instance of my Apache web
server susza studio now cues a launch in
Amazon web
services my Apache web server is now
launched you can verify this by going to
Amazon web services Management console
and select
instances then refresh and you can see a
running instance of my Apache web
server going back to Souza Studios
Amazon ec2 management page you can see a
URL is provided to the running instance
and by selecting it I will be taken to
the web page of that running apachi web
server so as you can see Suza Studio
provides a very easy way to build build
and upload appliances to Amazon web
services I am now going to terminate
that running instance by selecting the
terminate button and sua studio will
begin a shutdown of that running
instance the shutdown is now completed
if I go back to the Amazon web services
Management console refresh you can see
that instance is now
terminated siss Studio provides an easy
method to build and manage Amazon e to
Appliance images to be deployed in the
cloud thanks for watching and enjoy this
new exciting
feature
